did.unittitle: Lawrence L. Witt and Laura A. Edge papers 1943-2012, 1943-1946
did.langmaterial: The material is in English with some items in German.
did.abstract: Lawrence L. Witt was a Detroit native who served in the Army Air Force during World War II and was a prisoner of war (POW) for eleven months after getting shot down over Nazi Germany. His daughter Laura A. Edge later researched her father's story and wrote a book about his and other airmen's experiences as prisoners of war in WWII. Correspondence, various documents relating to military and prisoner of war experience, and audio-visual materials including oral histories of several WWII veterans.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: The collection was donated by Laura A. Edge (donor 11053) in 2014.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open to research.

userestrict.p: Copyright is held by the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: [item], folder, box, Lawrence L. Witt and Laura A. Edge Papers, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

processinfo.p: The Witt papers were organized, processed and digitized by the donor, Laura Edge. Bentley staff did some additional processing in preparing the digital files for deposit in Deep Blue, the University of Michigan Digital Repository. The finding aid reflects the series and folder structure of the paper records in boxes 1-2. The digital surrogates may be linked at the folder or item level or in some cases at the series or subseries level. In the latter cases a single links provides access to a multiple folders in the form of a compiled PDF file and a ZIP file of the original tiff images of the scanned items. The audio and video files were received on CD or DVD and have been transformed to WAV files (audio) and MPEG4 (video) files. These are sometimes bundled in a ZIP file that includes addition information about the audio or video file

bioghist.p: Born June 1, 1923 in Detroit, Lawrence Lee Witt served in the U.S. Army Air Force during World War II. On May 12, 1944, he was shot down over Nazi Germany. He was a prisoner of war for the next eleven months, primarily at the Stalag Luft IV prison camp, located in what is now eastern Poland.

Prior to enlisting in the army, Witt worked for the Ford Motor Company, and he enjoyed a long career there after the war as well. He attended the Ford Training School as a teenager and served as an apprentice before enlisting, initially earning a deferment for assisting in research vital to the war effort. Intending to serve as an airplane mechanic, he enlisted in the Army Air Force in December 1942. Due to shifting military needs, however, after training as a mechanic he was sent to gunnery school, and served as the flight engineer and waist gunner on a B-17 with missions over Nazi Germany.

Witt's plane was shot down on May 12, 1944 and he soon became a prisoner of war, along with four of his crewmates (five did not survive being shot down). From late May through early February, he was held at Stalag Luft IV in what is now Poland. In early February, the Nazis evacuated the camp in a forced march of several hundred miles west to Stalag 357. After avoiding yet another forced march, he was liberated by the British on April 16, 1945. Returning to the United States in May, his military service continued, mostly spent receiving treatment for the physical and psychological trauma he endured as a prisoner of war, before being honorably discharged November 1, 1945.

On January 26, 1946, Lawrence Witt married Lois Davis, whom he proposed to while on furlough in July 1945. Together they had three daughters, Laura, Ellen, and Ruth. Laura, intrigued by her father's history, conducted extensive research on her father's and others' war experiences through correspondence, oral history interviews, official military documents, and other sources. She published a book based on her research On the Wings of Dawn: American Airmen as Germany's Prisoners: Their Story of Courage, Sacrifice, and Survival, in 2012.
At nearly 87 years of age, Lawrence L. Witt died on April 10, 2010.

arrangement.p: The collection is organized in four series: Correspondence, Collected Materials, Oral Histories, and Audio-Visual materials.

scopecontent.p: The Lawrence Witt and Laura Edge papers document Witt's experiences during and after World War II, as well as his daughter's research on his and other airmen's experiences as prisoners of war in Nazi Germany. Most series consist of folders (both original and digitized copies) originally ordered and numbered by Laura Edge.

controlaccess.head: Subjects:
controlaccess.subject: Prisoners of war--Germany--Personal narratives, American.
Soldiers--Michigan--Correspondence.
controlaccess.corpname: United States. Army Air Forces. Bombardment Group (H), 96th.
controlaccess.subject: World War, 1939-1945--Prisoners and prisons, German.

scopecontent.p: The Correspondence series (1 linear foot and 12.0 GB, 1943-2012) includes both original and digitized versions of documents and is divided into three subseries: Family correspondence, Personal correspondence, and Research correspondence. Family correspondence contains letters and related materials sent or received by Lawrence Witt's mother, Gladys Collins. The bulk of the correspondence was sent by Witt himself, and much of that from when he was a prisoner of war (POW) in Germany. Also included are notifications sent by the Department of War about Witt's status, a few notes or letters to Witt, and related materials such as newspaper clippings. Personal correspondence primarily consists of letters sent between Lawrence Witt and his future wife, Lois Davis, but also includes a few letters from other friends and acquaintances. The bulk of this subseries was sent following the end of the war. The Research correspondence subseries contains letters related to Laura Edge's research on her father's and other airmen's experiences as prisoners of war in Germany during World War II.

scopecontent.p: The Collected materials series (0.5 linear feet and 14.8 GB, 1943-2010) includes originals, photocopies, and digitized versions of documents and is divided into three subseries: Military documents, Stalag Luft IV documents, and Miscellaneous. The Military documents subseries contains a variety of documents related to Lawrence Witt's military service. These include discharge papers, medical records documenting the physical and psychological implications of Witt's war experiences, certificates and diplomas, and other documents as well as copies of official military records that Edge requested as research materials. The Stalag Luft IV documents subseries consists of diagrams, notes, photographs, and printed materials related to the Stalag Luft IV prisoner of war camp. The Miscellaneous subseries includes the transcript of a serviceman John Anderson's diary, Witt's life story used at his funeral, and notes from interviews of Witt's crewmates.

scopecontent.p: The Audio-Visual materials series (4.1 GB, 2000-2012) is divided into three subseries: Photographs, Oral Histories, and Miscellaneous. The Photographs subseries includes digital copies of photographs from the Collected materials series as well as a range of family photographs dating from Witt's childhood to old age. Oral Histories includes audio and video interviews with Lawrence Witt and others, mostly about their experiences in World War II. Miscellaneous includes a documentary about life on the military base in Snetterton, England from 1943-1945 as well as an audio recording of Laura Edge presenting her father's life story to the Knox Presbyterian Church in Ann Arbor.
